answers.author: Lawrence Di Re
answers.text:
Megan,
The City of Dubuque has been doing this for a number of years and does it well.  Initiatives are supported from the City Council and City Manager's office to the staff, volunteer and appointed boards, to the community.  Here are some links as a start.  Most of these documents discuss city HR functions as well as community-wide projects.  You may have to sift through to find specifics more closely related to your particular question, but you get a good sense of how the City addresses diversity and inclusion.  Ms. Kelly Larson is the Human Rights Director there and she may be available to assist in your research.  Best to you and greetings to all back at SOG, btw.  http://www.cityofdubuque.org/DocumentCenter/Home/View/3623 http://www.cityofdubuque.org/DocumentCenter/View/16041  http://www.cityofdubuque.org/index.aspx?NID=1046

answers.author: Jessica Sharp
answers.text:
Hi Megan - National Research Center (NRC) conducts The National Employee Survey (The NES) for local governments across the country. The survey includes questions designed to measure diversity and inclusiveness and we'd be happy to share the results in aggregate. Feel free to email me for more information -- I'd be happy to put you in touch with The NES project manager.
Mary - I'd encourage you to look at our website (www.n-r-c.com) for more information about The NES. I'd be happy to send you a sample of the survey tool if you are interested!

author: Megan Dale
text: I am a graduate student at the University of North Carolina-Chapel Hill researching HR initiatives that intend to foster a more inclusive work environment and diverse workforce. I'm specifically looking for examples of how local governments evaluate the success of their diversity initiatives. Any examples would be appreciated!
title: Evaluating Diversity Initiatives
